title: Monday, 19th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 852.30, up 37.9 (+4.65%), High: 853.50, Low: 828.60, Volume: 1.80m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 192.00, up 7 (+3.78%), High: 192.05, Low: 187.75, Volume: 19.73m

11:14 am

BE

PM

Ah, shame

11:15 am
BE

It's like the 2014 merger speculation, except stupider.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse to tell you to buy Glencore.

BE

Upgrade to Outperform: dividend return in
sight, latent capacity growth in zinc & copper

11:15 am
BE

■ Action: Since our downgrade in mid-July the sector has been range bound
but the lift in coal prices gives us greater confidence in the deleveraging and
FCF generation of Glencore heading in to 2017. As the story progresses on
from balance sheet recovery we see three key drivers of outperformance
over the next 6-12 months: 1) FCF yields are highest of the peer group and
we expect this to translate into a sustainable dividend yield of ~5% from
2017; 2) as the most diversified major we have greater confidence in our
2017/18 cash flow estimates; 3) latent capacity in copper and zinc provides
~$1.4bn (14%) upside to current group EBITDA, an area the market is
currently placing very little value on.

BE

■ Dividend restart in sight: we have adjusted our model to reflect recent
divestments and, under our estimates, attributable FCFs (pre working capital,
post all capex, tax and interest) will improve to ~$3.5bn in 2017/18 and
translate into an underlying FCF yield of 10-11%. At spot prices this rises to
$4.4bn or 13%. We expect a cash flow based dividend policy and assume a
restart from early 2017.

BE

■ Zinc and copper latent capacity – asymmetric leverage: In H215 GLEN
suspended 500 kt of zinc and greater than 400 kt of copper capacity equivalent to 45%
and 30% of 2016 production volumes respectively. We expect these volumes
to be returned in a phased and 'market friendly' manner providing the group
with upside leverage to prices over the medium term. We expect the majority
of this capacity to be back on stream in 2019 and, at today's prices, these
volumes could increase group EBITDA by ~$1.4bn at very low investment.

11:16 am
BE

■ Valuations: we raise 2017 attributable EBITDA by 6% to $9.2bn largely on
higher thermal coal prices (from $55/t to $60/t) and note at spot prices
EBITDA sits at ~$10.3bn. We raise our Target Price from £2.1 to £2.2 based
on a target industrial EV/EBITDA of 6x, more than a 10% discount to our
target multiples for RIO and BHP.

BE

That's part of a bigger mining wrap, which I'll hoof up as well.

PM

Go on then

11:17 am
BE

Coal upgrades: One of the bigger surprises in 2016 has been China's coal
supply policy which has instigated a significant lift in thermal coal prices
globally and, over the past few weeks, a dramatic spike in coking coal
prices. We lift our thermal prices further from $55 to $60/t in 2017 (we
raised from $50 to $55 in August) and we raise coking coal prices from $94
to $119 and predict a Q4 settlement of $160/t. We leave our base metal
prices unchanged and reiterate our cautious view on copper and bullish
outlook for zinc.

BE

Dividend yields back into focus: Ironically enough, only 6-12 months
after the majors suspended dividend payments or broke away from long
held progressive policies, cash flows look set to improve materially in H216
and 2017. While we are not bullish on the outlook for the core commodities,
underlying FCFs and dividends look relatively attractive against the market
and this should provide a degree of valuation support. Large cap FCF
yields under our base case estimates are 8-11% in 2017 and lift to 10-14%
at spot prices. With the majors recently shifting to payout policies we
forecast base case dividend yields of 4-5% in 2017 rising to 6-7% at spot
prices compared to a market average of ~3.5%.

BE

Thermal and Coking coal outlook: Trying to second guess China
resource policy makes investors inherently nervous and unwilling to put any
kind of multiple on current high spot coal prices, particularly coking coal
which has surged to almost $200/t from below $100/t at the start of the
year. For thermal we forecast a pull back from ~$70/t to $60/t driven by
seasonally weaker demand post summer and a recovery in domestic
production in China. For coking coal we expect near term supply tightness
to progressively ease through 2017 and forecast a fall back to $100/t by
2018.

11:17 am
BE

Stocks: Our preferred names are BHP, GLEN, Boliden, Aurubis and KAZ.
Our earnings changes are summarised
later in this note and we make the largest upgrades to BHP and Anglo
which have the largest coking coal exposures. We have raised our target
prices across each of the large caps and now set a TP for BHP at £11.50,
RIO at £23, GLEN at £2.20 and AAL at £9.50.

BE

I'll save you the detail of the earnings upgrades, but here's the "spot vs not spot" chart.

BE

This isn't a great sign, surely? If there's one sector that should be able to earn money consistently and predictably from doing very little, it's the folk who dig up the roads.

Welcome to Markets LIve

BE

Here's Stifel.

11:31 am
BE

Operating profit to be materially lower than expectations for FY17E (10-20%, Stifel EBITA currently £131.5m), with weakness first half weighted. Effects of the EU referendum and cost legislation have impacted the Facilities Management business in 1H. Cost efficiency programmes are being implemented with a £10m cost in FY17E – with gross savings anticipated to be £15m in 2H17.

BE

Operating profit for full year to be materially lower than previous
expectations (10-20% lower). Sales are expected to be modestly up. The
effects of significant economic pressures – lower UK growth rates, public
sector budget constraints and uncertainty around the EU referendum – have
all impacted. Modest sales growth in Facilities Management will be offset by
weakness in local government facing Healthcare and Property Management
businesses.
1H17E to be especially weak with sales modestly lower and significantly
lower operating profit (35-40% of full year profit) due to a reduction in
higher-margin project work and discretionary spend by clients in Facilities
Management. The commencement of new contracts should support an
improved 2H17E.
Cost efficiency plans implemented across the group. One-off costs of
organisational change are expected to be £10m in FY17E, split evenly 1H/2H.
The expected gross savings benefits from these savings is expected to be
£15m in 2H17E.

BE

And Barclays, off the conference call.

11:31 am
BE

A long call but still somewhat lacking in detail. Key points: (1) Management believe that bottom-end of 5-6% margin target is still achievable for FY but will likely be below it in 1H. Applying a 5% margin to our FY revenue number (+0.6% yoy, in-line with management’s guidance for “a small amount of growth) implies operating profit of £112m which is 14% below previous guidance of £130m. Assuming a slightly higher interest charge (given lower profit = lower cash) and an unchanged tax rate, implies a FY17 EPS of c21.5p (vs our current forecast of 25.2p); (2) No comment on cash flow/net debt other than to say usual seasonality still applies, ie 1H outflow; (3) Healthcare – will update more on the future of this business at the interims but whatever the solution is it “will not involve significant cash outflows”; (4) Savings: taking out a number of management teams to realign cost base with current environment – these are permanent savings but the full-year effect of them in FY18 was not clear; (5) Apprenticeship Levy is potentially a £6m headwind in FY18 but should be some offset from Mitie drawing down to fund its own apprenticeships. Talking to clients about factoring this in but unlike minimum wage changes it is not cost pass-through as is new legislation; (6) Discretionary vs contracted: the softer environment for project work and discretionary spend was discussed a number of times during the call but we are still a little puzzled that spend in this area has been so different vs expectations outlined in March/May given many of the issues flagged in today’s statement are issues which had been discussed previously. Overall, a call which still leaves a number of questions unanswered ahead of the interim results in November.

BE

And Canaccord ........

BE

Whilst disappointing, the update highlights some encouraging recent contract wins such
as a material expansion on a recently won security contract which should provide some
support to the top line in the second half and into FY18. The longevity of the order book
(£8.5bn at May-16) and continuing strength of the pipeline (£9.1bn at May-16) within the
fragmented markets in which the Group operates is likely to throw up some opportunity
as smaller providers face up to the same challenges.
We also take some comfort from the fact that issues are relatively broad based across
the Group's segments with no specific operational failings and driven in the main by
client uncertainty, both economic and related to the transition of future service delivery
in the new cost environment. This transitional period is in our view understandable given
the current macro backdrop, and management remains confident that the impact will
prove to be relatively short term in nature as project works resume post the adjustment.
Valuation
Whilst we expect the shares are likely to underperform sharply today given the impact on
estimates, valuation continues to be relatively undemanding even on this reduced basis,
at a FY18E PE of 11x.
A conference call is to be held at 8am and is expected to provide some further colour on
operational changes and the market backdrop into 2017.
In advance and reflecting the changes to estimates we move our current valuation down
to 270p, maintaining the 12x PE basis of our target, in line with the Group's 5 yr average
multiple. Valuation has historically toughed at c10x +12m earnings.

BE

11:47 am
BE

Sky, maybe?

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 858.97, up 18.97 (+2.26%), High: 867.50, Low: 856.50, Volume: 1.93m
BE

I mentioned my theory about Sky gradually getting Napstered at the end of one of last week's sessions, and about 60 people got in contact to discuss the idea.

11:49 am
BE

Mostly saying, "ah, but streaming piracy is still underground" .... to which I wanted to say, "yes, but ABOUT SIXTY of you want to talk about it so it can't be that underground ......"

BE

Anyway, Morgan Stanley says "nothing to worry about"

BE

Structural fears have driven Sky shares down 25% ytd so that
it now trades at a c9% 2018e FCF yield and near its decadelow
p/e relative. Management's new targets and incentives
though imply c10% pa eps growth and 100p of eps by FY21.

11:49 am
BE

Sky won't exist by 2021. Just my prediction.

BE

Structural negative story dominates: The argument is that (i) Sky’s satellite TV
distribution model has been outflanked by over-the-top; (ii) this has allowed new
entrants (Netflix, Amazon Prime) into the market; (iii) integrated players (BT,
Virgin, Vodafone, Talk Talk) are investing in TV to support core businesses rather
than make a return in TV; (iv) Sky is undifferentiated in communications; (v) as a
retailer rather than producer of content, Sky is subject to fast-inflating prices for
key content (football, HBO etc) that drives customer loyalty; (vi) US cord cutting
is seen as a model for Europe; (vii) Sky's reduced KPI disclosure could disguise
underlying deterioration in subscriber characteristics; and (viii) eps forecasts are
subject to cost shocks (UK mobile launch, possible Champions League bid).

BE

And yet … In the last two years Sky has grown proforma revenues 5% pa, EBITA
8% pa and eps 5% pa. It faces a down eps year in FY17 on the incremental £632m
pa of EPL costs but has potentially two years of 20% pa eps growth in FY18-19.
Sky thinks there is 'a significant opportunity to step change our earnings again', has
just set new guidance of group revenue growth of 5-7% pa, EBITA growth ahead
of revenue growth and earnings growing even faster. Management is freshly
incentivised on revenue and earnings growth rather than KPI delivery. Sky aims to
deliver this through (i) UK price increases, a widening product range ( Now, Q) and
new services (AdSmart, SkyStore); (ii) greater penetration of underpenetrated
markets in Germany and Italy, using UK-style product initiatives and gradually
taking price; and (iii) reducing opex as a % of sales (new £200m cost saving plan
FY18-20) and via a falling tax charge.

11:50 am
BE

Upgrade to Overweight: We move to Overweight on Sky for the first time in four
years. Newsflow may improve starting with the CMD on October 22nd. After the
down year in FY17, we forecast 13% pa eps growth FY17-21 as Sky pursues its
long-term target of 100p of eps. Sky now trades at close to its lowest market
relative multiple in the last decade. Calendarised the stock is on a p/e of 13x
2017e and sub 11x 2018e with a FCF yield of 8.8% in 2018e, higher than the 5.6-
7.9% for US peers and one of the highest in European media.

PM

(That's quite a prediction Bryce)

PM

(But, having done a bit of research myself, certainly see the argument)

11:50 am
BE

Okay -- I should say that Sky won't exist in anything like its current form by 2021.

BE

But then, neither will we. Five years is a long time in media.

PM

cry smile

11:51 am
BE

Oh, and important disclaimer .....

BE

Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc is a corporate broker to Sky plc.

BE

So .... yep.

11:55 am
BE

Elsewhere ........

BE

We have a few sellside pushes of Weir

BE

(@Bluesky21: I'm reminded of Sky and Amstrad, with the former having a rather strong negotiating position over the latter as it was effectively its only customer.)

11:57 am
BE

I note mostly because there's been a bit of chat around Weir recently. Nothing firm.

BE

Here's JP Morgan saying buy.

BE

Despite the lack of earnings upgrades Weir has been one of the better
performing stocks in our industrial universe in recent months on the back of
rise in the oil price. We now suspect Weir is close to the point of inflection in
terms of its operating profit growth. We regard the new data on DUCs (drilled
but uncompleted wells) as encouraging. We believe this together with the
increase in the rig count results in the risk to consensus earnings forecasts for
Weir shifting to the upside. With 18% upside to our revised price target, we
are raising our recommendation to Overweight from Underweight.

11:58 am
BE

 Oil & Gas prospects improving. While the rig count is down by -40% y/y,
it is up by 25% from in the May 2016 low, and recently, capex spending
plans from a growing number of oil field service companies have been
raised. New data on DUCs points to a 10% decline in recent months. Given
the aggressive cost cutting, the operational leverage from rising volumes is
likely to be high. We have raised our revenue forecast and operating profit
forecast for 2017E by 5% and 56%, respectively.
 2017E EPS raised by 11%. On the back of the improving aftermarket
outlook for the Minerals and Oil & Gas divisions, we have raised our 2017E
group sales forecast for the group by 3% to £1,960m and the operating
profit rises by 10% to £272m. The Oil & Gas division accounts for almost
two thirds of the increase in our profit forecast. Our 2017E group EPS rises
by 12% to 82.2p from 73.5p.

BE

 Price target raised to 1,775p from 1,220p. Based on our revised forecasts
for 2018E and an EV/EBITA multiple of 14.0x, our Dec-17 target price
rises to 1,775p. At the low point of the last cycle, the group’s operating
profit margin was 8.4% (2005) and the EV/operating profit was almost 13x.
We believe the group is passing the cyclical trough with a margin of 12.3%.
 Valuation. Based on our revised forecasts, the group is trading on 2017E
EV/EBITDA, EV/EBITA and PE multiples of 12.1x, 14.9x and 18.4x,
respectively, a modest premium to our industrial universe. However, we
expect the EPS of Weir to rise by 50% over next couple of years, compared
with an increase of 14% for SXNP industrial universe. In our view, the
treadmill of earnings downgrades is coming to an end and the risk to
consensus forecasts is likely to be shifting to the upside, and this is not yet
fully reflected in valuation multiples.

BE

And here's Credit Suisse saying buy as part of a sector note.

11:59 am
BE

nitiating coverage of European Oilfield Services: The worst downturn
for a generation has seen over USD200bn (greater than 40%) of E&P capex removed
from the market, spurred widespread restructuring and tested many
balance sheets. But it has also been a force for good – the industry needed
to change after decades of poor operational performance. Unlike 2009, this
downturn has been sufficiently long to spur behavioural change – a leaner,
fitter and more returns-focused industry should emerge. This will take time
to be reflected in financial performance but valuations suggest the market
is prepared to look well beyond the current eye-of-the-storm.

BE

■ A phased recovery: We believe we’re close to the bottom, but growth may
be slow initially in 2017, with momentum building in 2018. We see a cycle
of reactivation rather than reinvestment as existing capacity is gradually
absorbed by growing demand. OFS must navigate a precarious low point in
the cycle with limited pricing power, balancing the need for asset utilization
with an acceptable level of risk that would not derail the recovery. We think
oil companies are poised to deliver improved operational/financial
performance. Selectively, OFS companies can share in this upside.

BE

■ Differentiation is key: There’s a lot to play for – we are tracking
~USD140bn of contract opportunities globally. Oil companies today have
different needs, looking more to OFS for technical expertise and innovative
project solutions, while pursuing new commercial models. Differentiation
through front-end expertise, technology, distinctive assets, execution track
record, even balance sheet, is more important than ever. OFS needs to
change with the times – many companies are rising to the challenge but
several are merely waiting for recovery to set in and could be left behind.

12:00 pm
BE

■ Top picks – Petrofac and Wood Group: Today we think the traditional
investor playbook for EU OFS will not work; stock selection is far more
important. Our preferred plays are Petrofac (retreating to a high-quality
core with optionality) and Wood Group (best-in-class early-cycle recovery
play, attractively valued). Our least preferred stocks are Subsea 7 (P&L
challenges, overly capital intensive), and AMEC Foster Wheeler (recent
outperformance excessive, headwinds underestimated). Our forecasts are
conservative – 5-10% below consensus – but we believe we are
approaching the end of the OFS downgrade cycle. We expect investors to
be looking through the trough to 2018.
